awd_titl_txt: Improving Data Quality of Advanced LIGO Gravitational-Wave Searches
awd_abstract_narration:
This award focuses on a specific task which is mission critical for the success of gravitational-wave astrophysics in the next few years: the improvement of data quality collected by the LIGO Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory (LIGO) detectors in future observing runs. Research will focus on (1) using existing techniques to identify and remove non-astrophysical noise in the data stream, and (2) developing new methods to build predictive models for detector noise. Broader impacts on the development of gravitational-wave astrophysics will consist in improving LIGO's search pipelines and the performance of the detectors. Educational and public outreach initiatives will strengthen programs aimed at yielding knowledgeable teachers with enough physics content to effectively teach physics courses in school. New initiatives to promote science among diverse segments of the population will be developed through collaborations with educators in other disciplines.

Removing non-astrophysical artifacts from gravitational-wave data is crucial for reducing instrumental noise non-stationarity, extending the detector network duty cycle, and increasing the statistical significance of gravitational-wave candidate events. Improvements in these areas, in turn, boost parameter estimation of the gravitational-wave detections and enable refined astrophysical interpretations of the signals. Personnel funded under this award will analyze data from LIGO detector output and auxiliary sensors with the goal to isolate and identify sources of noise affecting LIGO's gravitational-wave searches. Results from these investigations will be fed back to LIGO Laboratory commissioners and instrumentation researchers to assist in the mitigation of instrumental and environmental disturbances. At the same time, Mississippi students and researchers will develop new, fast, reliable and accurate methods to model instrumental noise in interferometric gravitational-wave detectors. Machine learning-based algorithms, such as genetic programming, will be used to build predictive models to uncover the origin of non-astrophysical noise in the detectors.

por.por_cntn:
This award focused on a number of mission-critical steps for the detection of gravitational waves of astrophysical origin by the LIGO Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory (LIGO) and Virgo detectors. It supported at different levels the scientific and educational activities of three postdoctoral scholars, four graduate students, and a number of undergraduate students.

Personnel funded through this award contributed to the operation activities of the LIGO Scientific Collaboration during the third LIGO-Virgo observation run, as well as during times of commissioning and instrument upgrades. Contributions to operations included characterization of the LIGO detector noise, instrument calibration, data quality shifts during observations, analysis of data from LIGO-Virgo searches for multi-messenger sources such as magnetars, core collapse supernovae, and gamma-ray bursts. In parallel, researchers and students conducted longer-term, research and development (R&D) activities aimed at interpreting detections, as well as building new physical models and tools to characterize gravitational-wave data. These R&D activities focused on using machine learning algorithms to uncover the origin of non-astrophysical noise in the LIGO detectors and remove its effect from signals, analyze physical models of bright gravitational-wave sources, improve the analysis pipelines of LIGO-Virgo searches from multi-messenger sources, and quantify the impact of overall calibration uncertainties and detector timing errors on the sky localization of these sources. Overall, the work performed in these areas successfully contributed to improving our understanding of the LIGO detection pipelines and the performance of the Advanced LIGO detectors. Outcomes include contributions to over sixty publications and preprints of the LIGO-Virgo-KAGRA collaborations,  nine short-authorlist publications in peer-reviewed journals, several presentations at conferences and workshops, and a number of technical notes.

The detections of gravitational-wave signals by Advanced LIGO and Virgo are a powerful means to promote science and the leading role of the National Science Foundation. In this context, this award supported broader impact initiatives that promoted gravitational-wave science to students and the society at large.  Broader impact activities included participation of all researchers supported by this award in local and regional education and public outreach events,  contributions to the educational and public outreach program of the LIGO Scientific and Virgo Collaborations, and service to the LIGO Scientific Collaboration.
